OK, so suppose we
have the model.

How do we estimate the
weights, the coefficients beta?
That's the question.

Well, this was Cox's, I
think, really ingenious idea.
This idea of partial likelihood.

And the magic of
it is they don't

have to specify that
baseline hazard, which

we've been saying so nicely
as unspecified without--

One does not have to specify it
and still get a good estimate
of the coefficients beta.

And we're going to
use-- what is done

is the same kind of
sequential in time logic

that was used to divide the
Kaplan-Meier curve and the log
rank test.

So if we're at a given time
yi, then the total hazard

for all the people
at risk at that time

is just the sum of
their hazards, right?
Here it is.

So this is sum over
all people that
were still at risk at a given--

they hadn't died or
been censored by time.
OK.

Then suppose we look at the
relative risk of the person who

died at that time versus all the
people that were at risk, right?

So kind of imagine
that at a given time,

we have a bag of colored balls
and with a certain probability,

we grabbed one of them, that's
the ball that had the event.

But we could have grabbed
one of the other ones.
So that's what's happening here.

The people that are at risk
that could have died, here's
their total risk.

And here's the person
that actually we
observed to die at that time.
Here's his risk.
His or her risk.
Oh, I see.

So you're saying
what's the chance

that the person
who actually died

was-- what's the
probability that they died
given their amount of risk.
Right .

And in the denominator,
you got all the risks

that were sort of
adding up to the pool.
Exactly.

What's the chance
that the actual death.

And the very nice thing is
that being a relative risk,

these h0's, the
baseline hazards, cancel

and we get a function
that's free of h0.

So whatever h0
is, we don't care.
We get this relative risk.

So this is the probability
under the model
of seeing the person die--

of observing the person who died
to actually die among all those
that could have died.
OK.
And notice the cancelation.
So now we simply--

just like we multiplied
the Kaplan-Meier,

we took products of
conditional probabilities,

now we take the products of
these probabilities, right,

which we just derived
one for one risk set,
now it's for all of them.

Remember any likelihood
is that the product,

if you have the sample-- or
independent sample, the product

[INAUDIBLE] the probabilities
of each of the observed samples.

So here it's the same
thing, except these--
this is the partial likelihood.
Exactly.

So this is, in a sense,
the probability of seeing,

of observing what we observed
under the model, which
is what likelihood is.

And then we're going
to find the values

of the parameters, the betas
that make this the highest.

So make the observed data the
most likely under the model.

And that's what maximum
likelihood is all about.
So here's an example.
Again, the same example before.

We have three failures,
the gold circles,
and these censored observations.

And these are the
relative risk functions

for each of the three failures,
just like we saw before.

They're only computed
at the death times.
Exactly.

Just like in
Kaplan-Meier, we only

compute the conditional
probabilities
at the death times.

But the censored
observations, they

appear in the denominators as
well as future death times.

And you can see
them here, right?
Right.

So for the first failure, we
compute that relative risk
function for beta.

Second, we compute the
relative risk function there.

Third, and we take
their product,

and this is the
partial likelihood.

It's just a function
of beta, which

is a P vector of our
weights for our features,

and now we maximize
this function over beta.

As in the case of
a lot of the models

we've seen like
logistic regression,

there's no closed
form solution so we

have to apply an
iterative algorithm.
But have to.
It's no problem.

It's done very easily
now in software.

And not only do we get what's
called the maximum likelihood

estimate, the partial
likelihood estimate,

we get the other goodies that
we've seen in least squares
in logistic regression.

For example, we get P
values of correspond

to particular hypotheses
like beta j equals 0, right?

That's often what
we want to know.
Is a feature important?

Is it contributing to the
risk of a patient as well

as standard errors and
confidence intervals?

So all the goodies
we seen from analysis

of variance and regression,
we get them here
in partial likelihood as well.
In partial likelihood.
OK.

Well, we've seen the
regression method.

We have a regression
method in hand.
We've seen the log rank test.

You remember in regression, we
test for coefficient being 0.

In the case where the
regressor is just a single 01,

what we get is something
equivalent to the t-test.
We remember this from our--

--a linear model, and you've
only got a single predictor--
Right.

--and let's say it's a
male female predictor, 01--
Right.
--and you test its coefficient.
Yep.

And what Rob saying is that's
equivalent to just doing
a two sample t-test.
Right.

If it wasn't equivalent, we'd
be pretty upset, wouldn't we?

Because we'd have two
very sensible ways
of testing the same thing.
If they didn't agree, we'd be--
I think we wouldn't be happy.

But in regression,
they do agree.

And it turns out the
same thing happens here

where now we have the
log rank test and Cox's
proportional hazards model.

In the case when there is
a single predictor taking

on two values, well,
we could either, again,

fit a Cox proportional
hazards model
or perform a log rank test.

But it turns out there's a bit
of [INAUDIBLE] in the book.

To extract a test from the Cox
proportional hazards model,

there's actually two or three
different ways to do it,

but one popular way is
known as a score test.

And happily, it turns out that
in case of a single binary

covariate, the score
test for testing bets

equals 0 in Cox's
proportional hazards model

is exactly equal to
the log rank test.

So just like the
t-test and regression

agree in linear
models, in Gaussian

linear models, the score test
for Cox proportional hazards

model is exactly the same
as the log rank test.
So it's a nice, tidy connection.
OK.

Some things we haven't discussed
in the proportional hazards
model.

You might have
noticed that there's
no intercept in the model.
And why is that?

Well, if you look
back at the model,

if we put an intercept
here, a beta 0 here,

we'd get an e to the beta
zero, which we could just

absorb into h0 of t, right,
because that was unspecified
anyway.

So I can put whatever I want
into here-- that's from here.

I can transfer it into here
if it's not a function of x,
and I wouldn't change the model.

And it would cancel out as well
when you do those ratios too.
Exactly.

So there's no
information about it.
Right.

So There's no point in
putting an intercept
because it doesn't contribute.

We talked a bit-- about in the
log rank test, the possibility
of tied failure times, right?

If time is measured
discretely like in months,

you might often get more
than one failure or death
at a given failure time.

And those are called
tied failure times.

As I mentioned,
the log rank test

can handle those
seamlessly while the Cox

model can handle them
as well, but it's
a little more complicated.

But if you look in the
software, which we mentioned

at the end of the course,
it's all been figured out
by smart people over the years.

And you might be wondering, why
the name partial likelihood?

Turns out it's not a full
likelihood in a sense

and this is a much
more technical topic.

But because of the
way it's constructed

with this unspecified h0
of t, it's very convenient,

but it's not what's called
full maximum likelihood,

but it's a very
good approximation.

So if you're interested more in
the underlying theory of this,
I suggest you read more.

Now we had started off talking
about the Kaplan-Meier survival

curves and how the survivor
function was a very important
summary of survival data.

Well, from the Cox
model, with covariates,

you also are interested not just
in the relative risk parameters,

but also the underlying
survival curve.

Now it's a function
of t given x, right?

You'd like to say given an
individual with certain feature

vector like males
or females or males

with certain clinical
measurements, what is
the predicted survival curve?

And you can get that
from the Cox model

as well, the entire
predictor survival

curve as a function
of their features.

So that's a bit different
from regression, right?

Usually with regression,
we just measure

the mean of the response
given x at any particular x.

Here, we get an estimate
of the entire distribution.
Exactly.

So let's look now at
the proportional hazards

model applied to the
brain cancer data.

And again, here's-- I mentioned
you get an ANOVA style table.
Here are the features.

Here's the coefficients,
their standard errors,

the z statistic, which is the
ratio and a two-sided p value.

And again, this is a
multivariate model,

much like the multivariate
models we saw in regression.
They're all fit together.

And the Karnofsky index is the
only one who's got a-- actually,

not the only one,
but these two--

The diagnosis-- one
of the diagnosis
is also very significant.
High grade glioma, right?

And again, this is one of the
brilliant aspects of this Cox

proportional hazards
model because it

takes this complicated problem
with censoring and so on

and it casts it as
a regression problem

with all the usual statistics
that makes it very usable.

And that's part of the
reason it caught on.
Right.

And the interpretation is
in terms of a relative risk.

So looking at Karnofsky
index, this x--

remember, this-- minus
this beta of minus 0.5

means that the relative risk
is exponential of minus 0.5
which is 0.95.

So it's saying
that if you have--
Each unit.

A one unit increase
in Karnofsky index

corresponds to a decrease
in the relative risk of 5%.

So that's something that's
often confusing making sure

you get the signs
of the coefficients

their interpretation
correct, right?

Here it's negative,
which you might normally
think is a bad thing.

But actually because
it's a relative risk

that's being modeled, being
negative here is good, right?

Because It's decreasing
the relative risk.

So that's an important
detail to keep in mind.

And this just reports
the p value, which

was truncated here but it's
actually from the actual table

Another example, the
publication data,

set which is mentioned
in the chapter,

this is the time to publication
of journal papers reporting

the results of clinical trials
reported by the NIH, 244 trials,

and the outcome is the time
in months until publication.

88 of them were not
published at all,

so they were censored
during the study period.

So this many were published,
and the remainder were censored.
They weren't yet published.

So the outcome was
time until publication.
Lots of covariates here.

And I won't read
through all of them

here but the one of particular
interest was whether or not--

if the clinical trial had a
significant positive result,

was it more likely to
be published earlier,

right, which is something that
I think some people believe.

So this study was one to look
at whether the positive result

of the clinical trial increased
the chance of it being published
more quickly.

And they wanted
to adjust for lots

of different possible
confounding factors.

Here's the Kaplan-Meier
curves for the two groups.

So ignoring the other
features at this point,

just looking at the
Kaplan-Meier curves,

it doesn't look like
there's much difference.

And sure enough, the log rank
test has a p value of 0.36.

So this is-- again, this
negative and positive result

refers to whether the
clinical trial reported

a negative or positive result
for the treatments being
compared.

And it looks like there's
not much difference.

And that's ignoring
all the other features.
Right.

But when we do a
multivariate analysis, again,

using Cox proportional hazards
model, what do we have here?

We have a very
significant p value
for positive result. Right?

The standard
error-- coefficient,

standard error in the
z-score, and the impact score

of the journal is also
important and some other guys
are marginally important.
So what's happened here, Trevor?

How could it be that these
survival curves are so similar

but this is strongly
significant?
It must be confounding.

So there's some
confounding factors here
that we had to adjust for.
Right.

Which is the reason
one does these kinds

of multivariate analysis, to
adjust for other confounding
factors.

And now the adjustments
been quite dramatic.

It now shows that a
strong positive effect

for a positive result in terms
of shortening the publication
time.
OK.

We can actually go
one step further

with this multivariate model
to produce adjusted survival
curves.

So we want survival
curves, the s of t

given x, the estimated survival
curves for positive or negative

results, and we want to
adjust for the other features.
Well--

When we first plotted
those two curves,

they were sort of averaged
over the other features.

The positive result group
and the negative result group

just averaged over
all the features.

And if those features
were differently

distributed in those
two groups, that's
when you have confounding.

So now we're going to
make sure the features are

the same in the two groups
when we look at the two curves.

That means we have
to choose some value
for those other features.

And one can choose any values,
but sort of the most reasonable
is to use the mean.

So we use the mean
value for each predictor

for things which
are not categorical

and for the categorical
prediction, which

is the mechanism of funding, we
use the most prevalent category,

So we set the features
to some fixed value

so we can make a
clear comparison
between positive and negative.
Oh, and look at that.

And now we see a
clear difference
between the survival curves.
Yeah.
What has happened?
